evidences.text: Sometimes the vertices are called nodes and sometimes the edges are are called links.
A graph can be undirected, which means the edges have no direction.
One to two is the same as two two.
It's like a one way street or a three two way street.
So undirected means two way.
They are both reachable from each other.
Or obviously it can be a directed graph.
In a directed graph, if I want to show it pictorially, I will put a direction on the edge, an arrow.
So this says there is a connection from 1 to 2.
There is not a connection from 2 to 1 in a directed graph.

A graph may be weighted, which means you have weight on the APIs.

So if I had a weight six and a weight three, so if I have a weight on every edge, which might be the importance of that edge, which could be the traffic on that edge, which could be the criticality of that edge, whatever that weight represents, we will call that a weighted graph.
And usually when we say weighted graph, we mean weight on the edges, not on the vertices.
You could have weight on the vertices in some cases, but typically not so weighted or unweighted.
There are other types of graph.

So if I give you a graph and I say show me a path in there, you gotta start from a vertex via an edge, go to the next vertex via another edge, go to another vertex, so on and so forth.
There are some paths that are short, there are some paths that are very long.
Path is exactly what it means.
Typically when we say a path, we mean a simple path.
A path that vertices are not repeated.
That's also a path where a vertex is repeated.
We call that a non-simple path if the vertices are repeated.
That's a simple path.
So when I want to talk about a path, I'm going to be explicit.
Is it a simple path or not?
If I don't say anything, you assume it's a simple path.
A cycle is a path with first and last vertex being the same exactly as the name suggests.
Some graphs may not have any cycle at all.
We call them acyclic graphs.
So a graph with no cycle is called acyclic.
